instruction: To differentiate between and classify different skin and tissue types in pig, what kinds of spectrum were used in the related study?
Output: To differentiate between and classify different skin and tissue types in pig, the visible spectrum and nir spectrum were used,spectra ranging from 450 nm to 1550 nm.

instruction: What spectral feature processing methods were employed to differentiate between and classify different skin and tissue types in pig?
Output: PCA and SVM were employed to differentiate between and classify different skin and tissue types in pigs.

instruction: Which metric was chosen to differentiate between and classify different skin and tissue types in pig using spectrum, and how far it go?
Output:
The metric chosen to differentiate between and classify different skin and tissue types in pig using spectrum were sensitivity and specificity values. The support vector machine was able to classify each skin and tissue type with an overall accuracy of 98.2%. 

The sensitivity and specificity values achieved for all skin and tissue types were between 96.4% and 100.0%.

instruction: What machine learning model was used to identify and classify the different skin and tissue types in the evaluation of the extended-wavelength diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (EWDRS) technique?
Output: The machine learning model used to identify and classify the different skin and tissue types in the evaluation of the extended-wavelength diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (EWDRS) technique was a support vector machine.

instruction: Can the extended-wavelength diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (EWDRS) technique be considered superior to traditional diagnostic methods for non-invasive tumor margin delineation, based on the ability to differentiate between and classify different skin and tissue types in an in vivo pig model?
Output: Yes. Based on the information provided in the related study, the extended-wavelength diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (EWDRS) technique shows promise as a potential diagnostic tool for non-invasive tumor margin delineation. The technique was able to differentiate between and classify different skin and tissue types in an in vivo pig model with an overall accuracy of 98.2%. The sensitivity and specificity for all skin and tissue types ranged between 96.4% and 100.0%. These results suggest that EWDRS has the potential to be superior to traditional diagnostic methods for non-invasive tumor margin delineation.
